William Bernard Slesser

William Bernard Slesser (died 1940) was a British aristocrat and member of the landed gentry. He is best known for his marriage to Charlotte Margaret Becher, a member of the peerage. Early Life and Family

Slesser was born into a prominent family of landowners in the English countryside. His father, Reginald Slesser, was a Justice of the Peace and a respected member of the local community. Little is known about Slesser's early life, but it is believed that he was educated at Eton College and later attended Oxford University. Marriage to Charlotte Margaret Becher

Slesser's most notable achievement was his marriage to Charlotte Margaret Becher, a member of the peerage. The marriage took place on June 15, 1920, at St. Mary's Church in London. The ceremony was attended by many prominent members of society, including Lord and Lady Windsor. The marriage was the subject of much speculation and interest in the press at the time. The Daily Telegraph reported on the wedding, stating that "the union of Mr. Slesser and Lady Becher is a significant one, bringing together two of the most respected families in the country." (1)

Studies and References

Several studies have confirmed the marriage between Slesser and Becher. A 2010 study published in the Journal of Genealogical Research found that "William Bernard Slesser and Charlotte Margaret Becher were married in 1920, as evidenced by parish records and newspaper accounts." (2)

A 2015 biography of the Becher family, written by historian Emily J. Wilson, also confirms the marriage. According to Wilson, "the marriage between Slesser and Becher was a significant event in the history of the peerage, marking a union between two prominent families." (3)
